I'm writing my review today to take a break with Brawlhalla. If you want to know my thoughts about it, feel free to read.

Brawlhalla is an interesting platform fighter. You have a ton of characters to choose from with different weapon combinations with 'em (with unique move set, I might add). All characters can be unlocked as you grind through the game. You can also unlock skins (or buy em especially the crossover ones with... a flip ton of Star Wars characters for some reason).  You can also modify your character's stats (not really, it is basically putting a point on either Dexterity, Strength, Speed, or Defense; though it's still good to be able to have those there).

Gameplay-wise, it is a solid platform fighter at it's core. A free-to-play fighter on that. 

HOWEVER, playing unranked (and even ranked) can be some of the most palpitating, STRESS-INDUCING plays in your life. Most people you will up against knows how to cheese (or even know how to play their character wonderfully) for the most part (ESPECIALLY the GOLD rank... I also heard the Platinum rank can be feisty as well). 

Additionally, there will be pricks that will emote you and drag you down if they win. If you're reading this, I will say that it's the part of ANY competitive game. It cannot be avoided. One thing's for sure, use this salt as a learning exp so that once you've went against that character again, you know how you will counter it. OK?

Now, for some tips in case you need it.

- There's a term the community calls "Sig-spamming." It is the way you over-using your signature attacks towards an opponent. While it is a strat you can do to annoy players (especially trying to rank up from the Bronze and Silver ranks), this is a VERY risky strategy. Why? it is because it will make you predictable AF. Any character's sigs has a weakness, and most players will be able to catch you up. TRUST ME, I know.

- Consider learning how to do combos in a weapon class/character. Seriously, this will help you significantly when it comes to dealing more damage than just poking your opponent. I wish I was able to do that when I've began my journey a long time ago.

- MOST IMPORTANTLY, if you are a beginner, disregard the tier list for a bit, and apply the "Rule of Cool" when picking the character you're about to play. If you like how your character plays, that's nice! If not, there are plentiful characters you can play.

Now, do I still recommend you to play this?

Honestly, I'm mixed about it. I can recommend you if you like competitive platform fighters. You can also play against your friends since it has online and couch multiplayer (afaik). 

If you want to play rank/unrank... prepare for war. It can be enjoyable for you, or put you into a rage inducing, keyboard breaking maniac. It is up to you.

This is why I'm taking a break in it. Seriously, I've been playing for more than 200 hrs, I terribly need to touch grass, man. 

Anyways, that's all. 

While my review states as recommended, please treat this one as a MIXED review.

Thank you.

And don’t even get me started on matchmaking — you’ll either stomp someone who just installed the game or get instantly launched into orbit by a level 200 sweatlord who hasn’t touched grass since 2018. Every match ends the same. You screaming at your screen, wondering why you’re still playing a game that clearly hates you. Overall, Brawlhalla is the perfect game if you love pain, laggy hit detection, and watching yourself get combo’d into next week. Truly a masterpiece of frustration. Would I recommend it? Absolutely not — unless you want to raise your blood presure for free.

[h1]Brawlhalla – 713 Hours Inside the Eternal Combo of Regret[/h1]
[b]Rating:[/b] ★☆☆☆☆ (2/10)

I have [b]713 hours[/b] in Brawlhalla. Not because I love it — but because I can’t escape it. This game is less of a fighting platformer and more of a psychological trap disguised as fun. Once you start, it’s over. Your free time? Gone. Your sanity? Questionable. Your soul? Property of Brawlhalla.

Every time I think I’m done, the game whispers, “just one more match.” Then it’s 2 AM, my controller is in pieces, and I’m questioning every decision that led me here. It’s not even that Brawlhalla is good — it’s that it’s [i]good enough to hurt you again tomorrow.[/i]

You win a game? Instant dopamine rush. You lose? Rage, despair, self-reflection. Then — queue again.
It’s a loop of sadness wrapped in colorful skins and fake triumphs. The matches blur together, your main becomes meaningless, and you start to realize the true final boss isn’t another player — it’s your own addiction.

The worst part? You’ll convince yourself you’re improving. You’ll grind, sweat, and cope — and then realize you’ve just spent another 100 hours circling the same emotional drain.

[hr][/hr]
[h2]Final Thoughts[/h2]
Brawlhalla isn’t a game. It’s a cycle, a beautifully cruel carousel of frustration and false hope. It gives you just enough joy to keep you chained to it — and enough pain to make you hate yourself for staying.

I don’t play Brawlhalla anymore because it’s fun. I play because [i]it owns me.[/i]

2025-11-27
Brawlhalla is a game that, for many players, manages to take the joy out of platform fighting and replace it with pure irritation. While some people love it, for others it can feel like a chaotic, unbalanced, and downright maddening experience. And honestly, it’s not hard to see why.

First off, the gameplay often feels like it rewards spam more than skill. Instead of encouraging thoughtful movement, smart punishes, or creative strategies, the game can devolve into a messy mash-up of repeated signature attacks that hit far too hard for how easy they are to throw out. When every other match turns into a “who can spam faster” competition, it sucks the sense of mastery right out of the experience.

Then there’s the weapon balance. Or rather, the lack of it. Every update seems to just shuffle the problem around instead of fixing it. One patch nukes your favorite weapon, the next one makes some random weapon feel broken beyond belief. For a competitive game, constantly feeling like your skill doesn’t matter because your weapon of choice is either a god-tier machine or a useless noodle is just exhausting.

Matchmaking doesn’t help either. If you queue ranked, you might find yourself fighting someone who plays like they’ve been grinding since the game’s beta, even if you're sitting in a lower tier. Nothing kills motivation faster than getting juggled for a full stock by someone clearly way outside your skill bracket. And in casual modes? Good luck avoiding the sweaty players farming for clips.

And don’t even start on the maps. Some stages feel like they were designed specifically to annoy you. Weird hitboxes on platforms, awkward kill zones, and layouts that reward cheap tactics over fair fights all contribute to a sense that the game is working against you, not with you.

Finally, the overall experience can feel repetitive as hell. Once the novelty wears off, you’re left grinding for cosmetics or climbing ranked in a system that frequently feels unfair and unrewarding. Combine that with the constant barrage of spammy playstyles, and the whole game can start feeling like a chore rather than something fun.

In the end, Brawlhalla is “the worst game ever,” 
Giros Statine

Brawlhalla is a very simple fighting game, which made it perfect for someone who wanted to get into the scene. Each character has the same model, with 4 distinct stats. They each have two different weapons, and while the light and aerial attacks are all shared between similar weapons, each character has their own unique special/heavy attacks. This game doesn't have that many complicated inputs, and those that could be considered complicated can be learned very quickly. The simplicity of the game was honestly one of the things that drew me into it.

I won't lie, when I did play Brawlhalla, I had fun. I would crash out when my ass was handed to me (I may or may not have lost a monitor to one of these crash outs), and got excited when I could find a random I could goof off with. But the game really isn't in a good spot right now. The new weapons that they add aren't really fun to fight with or against, and Blue Mammoth Games seems more interested in printing money with crossovers and skins than wanting to make an enjoyable game. Introducing a battle pass is - in my opinion - one of the worst choices that they have made with this game. The community is also one of the most toxic that I have had the misfortune of being a part of; I've heard it compared to the League of Legends community if that gives any indication. The developers thought that removing the post-game chat was the best fix for this (spoilers: it wasn't).

I've had an off-and-on again relationship with this game for close to 8 years now, and while I can honestly say I've had a lot of fun, I will be walking away from it for good. If you're thinking of getting into Brawlhalla, I would suggest finding another game.

Brawlhalla used to be my favorite platform fighter. I like the feel of the mechanics better than Smash Bros.

However, since switching to almost exclusively Macs several years ago, the performance is absolutely atrocious. It lags in every single game, the Chasm map is straight up unplayable due to lag for some reason, and the lag in general has gotten even worse recently to the point I don't enjoy the game at all. At first I thought maybe their servers are struggling with more traffic, but turns out the lag is just as bad vs. bots in a local match with WiFi turned off. I have an M1 Max capable of playing Shadow of the Tomb Raider at *ultra* settings *through translation layers*, and yet the 2D platform fighter is unplayable.

As I let my addiction go, this game will gradually join League of Legends in the list of competitive games I used to love but can no longer play because they are more focused on adding skins and tons more characters than actually maintaining a stable product.

In the last few years, this game has evolved into something else. For semi-casual gamers like myself, the game is occasionally unplayable due to people's unbelievable rate of improvement. I recently reached platinum, and I was quite pleased of myself for reaching this milestone. However, since then, I've only faced opponents with 1900+ elo and, most of the time, 2000 elo, which would be about diamond level. Given that I've only recently reached plat, it's obvious that I'm not diamond level. Now that everyone understands zero to death combinations, I am unable to play the game for enjoyment. Since I don't spend all day doing zero to death combinations in custom games and getting all of my characters to level 100 before ever hitting gold, I suppose it's a skill issue on my end. What I actually want to say is that Brawlhalla's ranking system is incredibly broken and unjust to people that want to enjoy themselves and progressively improve. I know it's a competitive game, but seeing players with 10 times the hours and 250 more elo in almost every match makes me want to give up. I wish everyone else who is playing Brawlhalla and experiencing the same problem the best of success and hope they reach their next milestone.
